title-group.article-title: Unmasking pseudopelade of Brocq in male adult: a rare case report

contrib-group.aff: aPakistan Institute of Medical Sciences, Islamabad, Pakistan

sec.title: Introduction and importance:
sec.p: Pseudopelade of Brocq originally describes asymptomatic, irregularly shaped patches of atrophic hair loss. It designates a rare, idiopathic, slow progressive cicatricial alopecia without evident signs of folliculitis or inflammatory changes. This dermatological disorder still needs further research into its pathogenesis and treatment. We hope this case report provides valuable insight and a significant addition to the research gap as it is common in females but rare in male patients, and serves as a starting point for additional inquiry regarding causal link and epidemiology of disease.

sec.title: Case presentation:
sec.p: The authors present a rare case of Pseudopelade of Brocq in a male adult patient. The patient initially presented with progressive hair loss, but later examination revealed multiple atrophic patches of hair loss in the vertex area without any signs of inflammation. Subsequently, the patient was treated with corticosteroids and showed improvement in disease progression.

sec.title: Discussion:
sec.p: The pathogenesis of the Pseudopelade of Brocq is not well defined. Diagnosing this clinical entity is challenging due to delayed presentation which leads to increased patient suffering, preventable complications like baldness, and economic burdens.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Pseudopelade of Brocq is a rare dermatologic manifestation. It is crucial to raise awareness among healthcare professionals regarding its delayed presentation to prevent its long-term complications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Pseudopelade of Brocq designates a rare, idiopathic, slow progressive cicatricial alopecia without evident signs of folliculitis or inflammatory changes[1]. Pseudopelade includes the end stage of various forms of scarring alopecia whereas pseudopelade of Brocq originally describes asymptomatic, irregularly shaped patches of atrophic hair loss mostly in white males. The disease progresses slowly with a random distribution of lesions commonly involving the scalp vertex. The classical presentation includes bald patches with “footprints in the snow” appearance which are white hypopigmented (porcelain) and depressed atrophic plagues[2]. This case highlights the importance of considering the pseudopelade of Brocq as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with cicatricial alopecia. This dermatological disorder still needs further research into its pathogenesis and treatment. We hope this case report provides valuable insights and a significant addition to the research gap.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: This case report has been formulated based on the SCARE guideline checklist[3].

sec.title: Case presentation
sec.p:
A 21-year-old male, who works as a driver presented with a 2-year history of progressive hair loss affecting the vertex of the scalp. He had no history of systemic illness, trauma to the scalp, medication, smoking, alcohol consumption, or any other drug abuse history. No family member had similar complaints or symptoms. Physical examination revealed multiple, irregularly placed smooth and shiny atrophic patches without any signs of inflammation in the vertex area of the scalp which is presented in Fig. 1. No other area of the body including cutaneous, and mucosal was affected and there was no involvement of the nail. The hair pull test was negative. Laboratory investigations included a complete blood count, thyroid function test, and autoimmune profile which were unremarkable. The differential diagnosis included discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE), lichen planopilaris (LPP), folliculitis decalvans (FD), follicular degeneration syndrome, and Alopecia areata. To reach a definitive diagnosis, a scalp skin biopsy was performed which revealed atrophy of the epidermis and fibrosis in the dermis with little to moderate follicular clogging as shown in Fig. 2. The diagnosis of pseudopelade of Brocq was made based on clinical findings and histopathological findings criteria defined by Otto Braun-Falco et al 1986[4] summarized in Tables 1 and 2. We started topical corticosteroids (Class 3) two finger-tip units (0.5 g) and tacrolimus ointment (0.1%) twice a day. The disease progression halted after 3 months.Figure 1.
Wide irregular, scarring alopecia on the vertex of the scalp. Figure 2.
Microscopic image of scalp lesion of vertex showing moderate follicular clogging and absence of sebaceous glands in the dermis without any lymphocytic infiltration. Table 1
Otto Braun-Falco et al 1986, clinical criteria to diagnose Pseudopelade of Brocq.
Clinical criteria
Female:male = 3:1
Moderate atrophy (later stage)
Slow progression with spontaneous termination possible
Long course (at least > 2 years)
Mild perifollicular erythema (early stage)
Irregular defined and confluent patches of alopecia
DIF = Negative or at least only IgM Table 2
Otto Braun-Falco et al 1986, histological criteria to diagnose Pseudopelade of Brocq.
Histological criteria
Fibrotic streams into subcutis
Absence of widespread scarring
Absence of significant follicular plugging
Presence of normal epidermis (only occasionally atrophy)
Absence or at least decrease of sabecous glands
Absence of marked inflammation

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The first report of the medical condition was made in 1885 in Paris by Brocq. Pseudopelade, named after the French word “pelade,” which refers to alopecia areata[5], is similar to alopecia areata clinically but differs in that it lacks follicular openings, which causes chronic patchy baldness. Primary pseudopelade is typified by an immune-mediated mechanism in which damage to stem cells in the isthmus (bulge area) is caused by perifollicular lymphocytic infiltrates, resulting in permanent hair loss. Idiopathic instances account for about 10% of cases, and few people have a hereditary propensity. “Secondary pseudopelade” describes the last phases of scarring alopecias, including morphea, DLE, FD, and LPP[6].

The cause of this condition has yet to be established. Pincelli et al provide an immunological explanation. Brocq’s childhood pseudopelade is uncommon, and this may be the first reported case in two if not three, family members. This shows that our patients have a separate cause, which may involve genetic variables. However, our patients did not show the normal HLA B8/DR3/DR4 pattern that is commonly associated with autoimmune disorders. A family history of autoimmune disease is not typically associated with this syndrome, and environmental variables cannot be ruled out[7].

A sparse or moderate lymphocytic Infiltrate around the infundibulum and the absence of sebaceous glands are pathologic hallmarks of an early PPB lesion. In later lesions, the follicular epithelium becomes more and more atrophic and follicles are often surrounded by concentric lamellar fibroplasia until finally the follicle is replaced by fibrous tracts. Unlike in DLE and LPP, the elastic fiber network is preserved and elastin stain might show markedly thickened elastic fibers[2].

Pseudopelade of Brocq is considered end-stage permanent alopecia leading to baldness in a few years. The pathogenesis of cicatricial alopecia includes the destruction of hair follicles and subsequent fibrosis. This can be due to damage to the hair follicle itself or damage to the reticular dermis which ultimately damages hair follicles. Stem cells are present in the hair follicle bulge which contributes to the regeneration of hair, loss of these cells results in lasting scarring alopecia[8,9]. Pathophysiology is yet to be understood completely and is subject to further research on the topic. No standard treatment for PPB is present. Treatment is usually resistant to topical corticosteroids, 5% minoxidil, and intradermal steroids. Oral steroids are ineffective. If the disease is stable for at least 2 years, surgical options may be considered. It can include scalp reduction surgery or hair transplantation (autologous)[2,10]. The pseudopelade of Brocq is insidious in onset, and slow in progression. The diagnosis is based on exclusion without any permanent cure[2].

Our case study sheds light on the rare presentation of Pseudopelade of Brocq in adult male patients. It is vital to recognize its limitations as our research is observational and cannot demonstrate the pathogenesis of the disease. Pseudopelade of Brocq which is common in females but rare in male patients, serves as a starting point for additional inquiry regarding causal link and epidemiology of disease.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our patient presented with slowly progressive irregular patches of atrophy in the vertex area of the scalp. There was no evidence of any other systemic and cutaneous illnesses that established the diagnosis of idiopathic PPB. To reduce the progression of disease proper evaluation through examination and biopsy should be done. The disease is treatable with steroids and the patient should be followed along the course of the disease.

fn.p: Sponsorships or competing interests that may be relevant to content are disclosed at the end of this article.

sec.title: Patients’ perspective
sec.p: According to the patient, her disease progression decreased after topical corticosteroids and tacrolimus ointment use including progressive hair loss affecting the vertex of the scalp and shiny atrophic patches. She was satisfied with the care provided to her.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: Ethics approval was not required for this case report.

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal on request.

sec.title: Sources of funding
sec.p: The authors received no extramural funding for the study.
